Great story of human perseverance.  An illuminating history of life under a totalitarian secular society.  Citizens of any democracy should take note!

I lived in Bratislava, Slovakia from 1992 to 2002; visited Praha 3 or 4 times. It is stunning that one woman could endure this non-stop series of nightmares! It enlightened me afresh what my Slovak friends had endured prior to our arrival there. I wish she had mentioned that the leader of the Prague Spring, Dubcek was a Slovak. She endured so much under the hands of the 20th Century's biggest monsters: Hitler and Stalin.
This is a really good read for an understanding of WWII and post-war Hungary. Easy read for undergraduate students

This biography adds to the accounts of life ("existence" is a better word) under a totalitarian regime.  It relates the senselessness of life, and the waste of life and talents.  I saw this book mentioned somewhere and thought it would be interesting to read as I hadn't read anything about oppression in Czechoslovakia.  I came away realizing more clearly that freedom is precious and we have to do all we can to protect and promote it.We read this in our parish book club and it was generally well-received with a recognition of the loss which Heda Margolius Kovaly and a whole nation experienced.  It is an easy book to read and well worth it.
Upsetting as are all stories about life under repressive regimes.

I bought this book in a little shop in Prague, it is a essential reading, the story is very sad, but the tone is not tragic or suffers of what would amount to understandable self pity, It is a great book under every light.

summary:
Heda Margolius Kovaly's steady gaze at the lives caught up in Czechoslovakia's tragic fate under the Nazis and then during the Stalin era illuminates the chaotic life of a nation. Kovaly was deported to concentration camps, escaped from a death march, nearly starved in the post-war years, only to be shattered by her husband's conviction (in the infamous 1952 Slansky trial) and his execution. Resonant with lyricism, this gripping memoir is uplifting even in the midst of horror.

“Once in a rare while we read a book that puts the urgencies of our time and ourselves in perspective, making us confront the darker realities of human nature... Mrs. Kovaly experienced the two supreme horrors of what Hannah Arendt called this terrible century. But her book is not just a personal memoir of inhumanity. In telling her story – simply, without self-pity – she illuminates some general truths of human behavior... Quietly, with cumulative force, it shows us how the totalitarian state feeds on the blindness and the weakness of man.” The New York Times
